Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
The epic tradition: Homer, The Iliad, Book 22
Refer to pages 2-3 in the Stimulus Book when responding to this question.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Outline the events that take place immediately after this extract.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Describe how Achilles is depicted in this extract. 

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Explain the techniques used by Homer to create pathos in this extract.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Using evidence from this extract and Book 22 as a whole, analyse Homer's
exploration of the role of the gods.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
The epic tradition: Virgil, The Aeneid, Book 12
Refer to page 4 in the Stimulus Book when responding to this question.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Outline the events that take place immediately before this extract.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Describe how Turnus is depicted in this extract. 

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Explain the techniques used by Virgil to create tension in this extract. 

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Using evidence from this extract and Book 12 as a whole, analyse Virgil's
characterisation of Aeneas. 

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Material culture: The Parthenon
Refer to page 5 in the Stimulus Book when responding to this question.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Identify the figures in the image. 

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Identify and explain the techniques used to create the relief in the image. 

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Describe the myth depicted in the image. Explain why this myth was chosen. 

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Analyse how the location and construction of the Parthenon as a whole reinforced
Classical Athenian ideas and values.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Material culture: The Colosseum
Refer to page 6 in the Stimulus Book when responding to this question.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Identify the architectural features marked A and B on the image. 

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Identify and explain the techniques used to construct the Colosseum. 

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Explain Vespasian's reasons for building the Colosseum. 

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Analyse the social function of the games held in the Colosseum.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Section B: Classical perspectives

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Instructions

Subject: Classical Studies
Content: Write your response in English.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Aeschylus, Prometheus Bound and Plato, Apology
'Prioritising principles comes at great personal cost to the individual.'
Evaluate this statement using evidence from the works studied this year.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Aeschylus, Prometheus Bound and Plato, Apology
'Breaking the rules can never be justified.'
Evaluate this statement using evidence from the works studied this year.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Euripides, The Bacchae and Ovid, Metamorphoses
'Change is inevitable, but identities are fixed.'
Evaluate this statement using evidence from the works studied this year.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Euripides, The Bacchae and Ovid, Metamorphoses
'Males act only for their own benefit.'
Evaluate this statement using evidence from the works studied this year.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Aristophanes, Lysistrata and Thucydides, History of the Peloponnesian War
'In war, there is always more lost than gained.'
Evaluate this statement using evidence from the works studied this year.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Aristophanes, Lysistrata and Thucydides, History of the Peloponnesian War
'Strong leadership is of the greatest importance.'
Evaluate this statement using evidence from the works studied this year.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Livy, The Rise of Rome and Tacitus, The Annals of Imperial Rome
'Ancient authors presented Rome as entirely corrupt.'
Evaluate this statement using evidence from the works studied this year.

Subject: Classical Studies
Content:
Livy, The Rise of Rome and Tacitus, The Annals of Imperial Rome
'Hierarchy must be preserved in ancient Rome.'
Evaluate this statement using evidence from the works studied this year.
Indicate the number of the question you are answering in the box.
Extra space for responses
Clearly number all responses in this space.
If you use any additional Question and Answer Books to complete your responses, write your student
number on the front cover. At the end of the examination, place the additional Question and Answer
Books inside the front cover of the first Question and Answer Book.
Assessment criteria for Section
The essay will be assessed against the following criteria:
•	 knowledge of the two classical works, and their relationships to their socio-historical
contexts and the classical concern
•	 analysis of key ideas and the features and techniques used to explore these ideas in
the two classical works
•	 construction of a comparative argument in response to a topic, with a focus on the
comparison of key ideas and the features and techniques used to explore these ideas
•	 use of relevant evidence
